reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The president made a huge blunder and he tried to cover it up, but it backfired.
examples.ja: 社長は大失態を犯し、それをごまかそうとしたが、それがかえってアダとなった。

examples.en: Since the 2017 fiasco, Koichi has locked himself in his room and refuses to come out.
examples.ja: ２０１７年の失態から、コウイチは部屋に引きこもって出てこなくなってしまった。

examples.en: The president, who had made a terrible political blunder, could not hide his frustration.
examples.ja: とんでもない政治的失態を演じた大統領は、苛立ちを隠せないでいた。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>appearance</kanji> of <kanji>fault</kanji> is a huge <vocabulary>blunder</vocabulary> on our family. At least do not have the appearance of fault.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The しつ gets shortened to しっ, though, so don't make that <vocabulary>blunder</vocabulary>.

examples.en: I sent a congratulations card to my nephew when he passed his high school entrance exam.
examples.ja: 甥っ子が高校の入学試験に合格した時に、祝賀状を送りました。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji> Congratulations</kanji> on your <kanji>condition</kanji>. I'll send you a <vocabulary>greeting card</vocabulary> to make it official. Though this kind of card is almost always in the form of a <vocabulary>New Year's Card</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: It's difficult to judge whether it's an edible or poisonous mushroom.
examples.ja: 食用キノコか毒キノコかを判断するのは難しい。

examples.en: It's often said you shouldn't judge people by their appearance, but do you think that's really true?
examples.ja: よく人を見た目で判断してはいけないと言いますが、それは本当に正しいことだと思いますか？

examples.en: Judging from what I've heard, the best seems to have been saved for last.
examples.ja: これまでに聞いたことから判断すると、どうやら真打ちは最後にあるようだね。

meaning_mnemonic: 判断 is judgement. Make that into a verb and you have <vocabulary>to judge</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to conclude</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know 判断 before learning this, but if you don't I won't judge you (the Crabigator will).

examples.en: I won't be sending out New Year's cards this year.
examples.ja: 今年は年賀状は出しません。

examples.en: I got a New Year's greeting card with Koichi's picture from Tofugu.
examples.ja: トーフグから、コウイチの写真付きの年賀状が送られてきました。

examples.en: Let's have Aya draw the illustration for the New Year's card next year.
examples.ja: 来年の年賀状のイラストをアヤにかいてもらおう。

examples.en: In Japan, there is a tradition of sending each other New Year's cards.
examples.ja: 日本では、新年に年賀状を送り合う伝統があります。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>year</kanji> <kanji>congratulation</kanji>s <kanji>condition</kanji> is when you tell the world about your condition for the new year. What's a better way to tell them than by using a <vocabulary>New Year's Card</vocabulary>?
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Nothing was impossible for invincible Superman.
examples.ja: 無敵のスーパーマンに、不可能なことは何もなかった。

examples.en: It's impossible to be a political observer when you aren't interested in politics.
examples.ja: 政治に関心が無いのに政治評論家になるのは不可能だ。

examples.en: In the poker tournament, I had a bad feeling, but it wasn’t possible for me to fold my hand.
examples.ja: あのポーカーのトーナメントで、悪い予感はしてたんだけど、捨てるのは不可能な手札を持っていたんだよ。

meaning_mnemonic: You already know how 可能 means possible. So when you add <kanji>not</kanji> it becomes <vocabulary>impossible</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know how to read 可能 first as well.

examples.en: I don't want to criticize you, but this is just terrible.
examples.ja: 君を非難するつもりは全くないんだけど、これはひどすぎるよ。

examples.en: I was blamed by the other club members for not going to the summer training camp.
examples.ja: 夏の合宿に参加しないことを、他の部員達から非難されました。

examples.en: The kids criticized their parents for hiding the scandal.
examples.ja: 子どもたちは両親が不祥事を隠したことを非難した。

meaning_mnemonic: Know how 非難 is a criticism? Make it a verb and you have the word <vocabulary>to criticize</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Of course, it will be really helpful to know the word 非難 to start.

examples.en: What food do you really hate?
examples.ja: 大嫌いな食べ物は何ですか。

examples.en: I heard that there are some people in the world who hate Tofugu.
examples.ja: 世の中には、トーフグのことが大嫌いな人もいるらしい。

examples.en: Mr. Viet will meet with you instead of Mr. Koichi because Mr. Koichi really hates you.
examples.ja: コウイチはあなたのことが大嫌いなので、彼に代わってビエトがお会いします。

meaning_mnemonic:
Remember how 嫌い is to <kanji>dislike</kanji>? When that dislike is <kanji>big</kanji>, you really dislike it. That means you <vocabulary>hate</vocabulary> (or <vocabulary>really hate</vocabulary>) it.

As with 嫌い, a more literal translation is <vocabulary>detestable</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the reading for 大, and the reading for 嫌い is like the one you learned with 嫌い in level 20.

examples.en: When I woke up, a tree had fallen in front of my house. It was probably toppled by the wind.
examples.ja: 起きたら家の前に、木が倒れていたんです。おそらく風で倒れたんでしょうね。

examples.en: He got knocked down in the 1st round.
examples.ja: アイツは第一ラウンドで倒れちまったんだよ。

examples.en: The marathon runner collapsed from exhaustion right before the finish line.
examples.ja: そのマラソン選手は、ゴールの直前で疲れきって倒れてしまいました。

meaning_mnemonic: You've seen how 倒す is "to knock over." But this is when something gets knocked over by itself. You know that you're not doing anything here, because when you're not touching all these fine glass items, it's very <reading>rare</reading> (れる) that anything gets knocked over (because you're not touching anything, you clumsy dumsy). It's also when you or someone else collapses. You didn't push yourself over, you just kind of fell by yourself.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same like 倒す. If you knew 倒す you will know the reading of this one too.

examples.en: Don't skip over my turn!
examples.ja: 僕の順番を飛ばさないでよ！

examples.en: When Koichi cracks a boring joke, Viet gets grumpy.
examples.ja: コウイチがつまらない冗談を飛ばすと、ビエトは不機嫌になる。

examples.en: Fugu sent a triple flying over center field.
examples.ja: フグは、センターオーバーの三塁打をかっ飛ばした。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how 飛ぶ is to fly? Well this word is for when you make some thing fly. So, this word is <vocabulary>to let something fly</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to send something flying</vocabulary>. It also means <vocabulary>to skip over something</vocabulary>, such as someone's turn or a question on a test.
reading_mnemonic:
The reading is just like 飛ぶ, so if you know that reading you're close. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember the second part:

You can use your strength <vocabulary>to let something fly</vocabulary>, and that something is a <reading>bus</reading> (ばす). You're that buff!

examples.en: You should make sure the door is properly locked.
examples.ja: ちゃんとドアにカギをかけたかどうか確かめた方がいいですよ。

examples.en: Verify that the alcohol content has been completely removed.
examples.ja: アルコール分がちゃんと飛んだかどうか、確かめてくださいね。

examples.en: Kanae always checks the dictionary to make sure there are no mistakes in word use.
examples.ja: いつも、カナエさんが単語の使い方に間違いが無いか、辞書で確かめてくれています。

meaning_mnemonic: Like with 確か, which means <kanji>certain</kanji>, this is the verb version of that. So when you "do certain" you are going <vocabulary>to make sure of</vocabulary> something or you're going <vocabulary>to verify</vocabulary> something.
reading_mnemonic: This one is kun'yomi followed by okurigana. If you remember the reading you learned with 確かに, you should know this one!

examples.en: Taking a shower every day is such a bother.
examples.ja: 毎日シャワーするのって、本当に面倒臭い。

examples.en: There's nothing more annoying than listening to people complain.
examples.ja: 人のグチを聞くことほど面倒臭いことは無い。

examples.en: I've started going gray, but it's too much bother to color it.
examples.ja: 白髪が出てきちゃったんだけど、白髪染めをするのは面倒臭いんだよね。

meaning_mnemonic: Something is a trouble (面倒) and it is smelly (臭い). So what is something that's smelly and a trouble? Well, something that's <vocabulary>troublesome</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>a bother</vocabulary>, I suppose. Basically you can ignore the smelly part. For some reason someone threw that back in, but smelly things are a bother, I suppose.
reading_mnemonic:
The reading is the words 面倒 plus 臭い added together, so it is めんどうくさい!

Although the proper reading is めんどうくさい, be aware that people often just say めんどくさい when speaking. That extra う is just such a bother, you know?

examples.en: If you use this coupon, it'll be ten dollars cheaper when you do your checkup.
examples.ja: このクーポンを使えば、検査する時に10ドル安くなります。

examples.en: I had a doctor examine my ears yesterday.
examples.ja: 昨日、お医者さんに耳を検査してもらいました。

examples.en: I'm going to have the quality of my tap water tested next time.
examples.ja: 今度、水道水の水質を検査する予定です。

examples.en: After first examining the condition of the teeth and gums, we will proceed with cleaning off the plaque and tartar.
examples.ja: 初めに歯と歯ぐきの状態を検査してから、プラークと歯石のクリーニングを行います。

meaning_mnemonic: You know that 検査 is inspection, so the verb version of that would be <vocabulary>to inspect</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know 検査 already as well.

examples.en: I was supporting Takahashi Minami of AKB48.
examples.ja: 僕は、AKB４８の高橋みなみを応援していました。

examples.en: Who in the world was that campaign supporter who cheered fervently and loudly during the speech?
examples.ja: 応援演説で熱心に声を出してたあの応援者は、いったい誰だったんだ？

examples.en: I was chosen to lead the Tofugu cheerleading squad, but I had no idea what to do, so I asked my predecessor for advice.
examples.ja: トーフグ応援団の応援団長に選ばれたが、何をしていいか分からなかったので、前任者の応援を求めた。

meaning_mnemonic: You must <kanji>respond</kanji> with <kanji>aid</kanji> in order to show your <vocabulary>support</vocabulary> for someone who needs it. You can usually show your support if you <vocabulary>root for</vocabulary> them.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I've been slacking off on updating my blog lately.
examples.ja: 最近ちょっと、ブログの更新をサボってるんだ。

examples.en: I need to renew my license soon!
examples.ja: もうすぐライセンスの更新手続きをしなきゃいけないんだよね！

examples.en: I need to apply for an extension of my visa by the end of next month.
examples.ja: 来月末までに在留期間の更新許可申請をする必要があります。

examples.en: They are proposing an updated contract with several alterations, but I’m still reluctant.
examples.ja: 先方は、いくつかの修正を伴う契約更新を提案してきているんだが、あまり気が進まないんだよね。

meaning_mnemonic: You’re <kanji>renew</kanji>ing something to become <kanji>new</kanji> again. We’re talking about a <vocabulary>renewal</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>update</vocabulary> to something.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Please change your password.
examples.ja: パスワードの変更をしてください。

examples.en: What if you ask them to change the size?
examples.ja: サイズ、変更してもらったら？

examples.en: Is changing the course for the dinner I had reserved something I can still do now?
examples.ja: 予約していたディナーのコースの変更って、今からできますか？

meaning_mnemonic:
Things that <kanji>change</kanji> and <kanji>renew</kanji> are going through <vocabulary>alteration</vocabulary>s and <vocabulary>change</vocabulary>. Pretty straightforward!

Unlike 変化, which is used for spontaneous changes, 変更 is used for deliberate or planned changes, like changing an appointment, modifying rules, or altering a plan.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Please be careful not to leave any belongings behind when getting off.
examples.ja: 降車の際は、お忘れ物にご注意ください。

examples.en: The taxi door will open automatically when you get off.
examples.ja: タクシーのドアは降車時に自動で開きます。

examples.en: There were too many people, so I couldn't reach the stop button.
examples.ja: 人が多すぎて、降車ボタンに手が届かなかったんです。

examples.en: "What did you think of that roller coaster?" "It was so intense that I threw up right after getting off."
examples.ja: 「あのジェットコースター、どうだった？」「すっごく良かったから、降車した瞬間にゲロっちゃったよ。」

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Descend</kanji> off the (train) <kanji>car</kanji>. You are <vocabulary>getting off</vocabulary> a train, or a bus, or anything else with wheels.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Please undress before taking a bath.
examples.ja: 脱衣をしてから入浴してください。

examples.en: I forgot my Apple Watch in the changing room.
examples.ja: 脱衣所にアップルウォッチを忘れてしまいました。

examples.en: I used a wheelchair to take my mother to the bathroom door, then helped her undress.
examples.ja: 車イスで母を風呂場のドアの前まで運び、脱衣を手伝いました。

meaning_mnemonic:
If you <kanji>undress</kanji> from <kanji>clothes</kanji> you are <vocabulary>undressing</vocabulary>.

脱衣 is a relatively formal word that you'll mostly see on the signage for changing rooms at public baths, where they'll be called 脱衣所 or 脱衣場.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The restroom is straight and to the left.
examples.ja: お手洗いは、真っすぐ行って左です。

examples.en: James always takes a sip of whiskey before going to the bathroom.
examples.ja: ジェームスはいつも、お手洗いに行く前にウィスキーを一口飲む。

examples.en: I dozed off while sitting in the bathroom doing my business.
examples.ja: お手洗いで用を足しているうちに、座ったまま寝てしまいました。

meaning_mnemonic: You know that 手洗い is "handwashing" (and also a not as polite way to mention a bathroom). When you add お you're suddenly making it polite. Why? Because you're talking about something a little more crass than handwashing. You're talking about the <vocabulary>toilet</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>restroom</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>bathroom</vocabulary>. Ewww. Poop goes there.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 手洗い, so if you know that you'll know this too!

examples.en: What do foreigners need when they stay in Japan?
examples.ja: 外国人が日本に在留する時に必要になるものは何ですか？

examples.en: Of course, I am residing in Japan with residence status.
examples.ja: もちろん、私は在留資格を持って、日本に在留しています。

examples.en: I have a limited amount of time to stay in this country.
examples.ja: 私がこの国に在留することができる期間は限られているんです。

meaning_mnemonic:
If 在留 is <kanji>residence</kanji>, then the verb version of that would be <vocabulary>to reside</vocabulary>.

Like 在留, this is also a more formal term. You might encounter it at the immigration office, but you probably won't hear it in everyday conversation.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 在留 so you should be able to read this one already!

examples.en: I don't like people who get upset easily.
examples.ja: すぐ不機嫌になる人は嫌だ。

examples.en: Hey, don't make such a sullen face. Let's have fun!
examples.ja: そんな不機嫌そうな顔しないでさ。楽しもうよ！

examples.en: I went to bed late last night and had to get up at five in the morning, so I was grumpy all day today.
examples.ja: 昨日遅く寝たのに朝五時に起きなくてはいけなかったので、今日は一日中不機嫌だった。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how 機嫌 means mood? Well when you add <kanji>not</kanji> it becomes a <vocabulary>bad mood</vocabulary>. It's so bad it's like you have no mood at all.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: My alcoholic father's hands were always shaking.
examples.ja: アル中の父の手は、いつも震えていた。

examples.en: When I found a painting of great value at a flea market, I trembled.
examples.ja: すごく価値のある絵をフリーマーケットで見つけた時、全身が震えました。

examples.en: I couldn't stop crying when I saw a puppy shivering from the cold.
examples.ja: 寒さで震えている子犬を見ると、涙が止まらなくなりました。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>earthquake</kanji> so the verb means <vocabulary>to shiver</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to shake</vocabulary>, like you would if there was an earthquake happening right now.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You start <vocabulary>to shake</vocabulary> in an earthquake because you're really <reading>full</reading> (ふる) from eating lunch. Now your full belly is shaking and quaking with the ground! Ahh it's awful! You never want to be full again!

examples.en: It's fine to leave your clothes on.
examples.ja: 衣服は着たままでかまいませんよ。

examples.en: Please put the clothes you've taken off here.
examples.ja: 脱いだ衣服はこちらにおいてください。

examples.en: This material makes any dirt on your clothes stand out.
examples.ja: この素材は、衣服のよごれが目立ちます。

meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>Clothes</kanji> <kanji>clothes</kanji> are also known as <vocabulary>clothing</vocabulary>!

衣服 is slightly more formal than the everyday word 服. It's kind of like saying "clothing" or "<vocabulary>garment</vocabulary>s" instead of just "<vocabulary>clothes</vocabulary>."
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: What’s the price of this item?
examples.ja: この商品の価格はいくらですか？

examples.en: The cost is a little too high, isn't it?
examples.ja: この価格はちょっと高すぎやしないかい。

examples.en: The price of raw materials for kendo masks has risen dramatically.
examples.ja: 剣道のお面の原材料の価格が急激に値上がりしている。

meaning_mnemonic:
When you <kanji>value</kanji> <kanji>status</kanji> you really care about the <vocabulary>price</vocabulary> of things. And usually the higher the <vocabulary>value</vocabulary>, the higher the <vocabulary>cost</vocabulary>.

価格 refers to something's market value, or to product pricing in a broader sense. It's sort of a formal word, so you might see it on fliers or in business and economic discussions about pricing strategies, for example.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: If a stranger suddenly put his hand on your head, you would surely feel disgusted.
examples.ja: 知らない人から急に頭に手を置かれたら、そりゃあ嫌悪感を感じるでしょう。

examples.en: Since then, whenever I see wisteria vines, I can't help feeling disgusted.
examples.ja: それ以来、藤づるを見ると、どうしても嫌悪感にかられるんです。

examples.en: I’m always filled with disgust when I talk with you.
examples.ja: あなたと話していると、いつも嫌悪感を抱くんです。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Bad</kanji> <kanji>feeling</kanji>s that you <kanji>dislike</kanji> are <vocabulary>unpleasant feelings</vocabulary>. These unpleasant feelings include things like hatred, disgust, revulsion, and fear. All of those are considered to be a part of the term unpleasant feelings.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned these readings already so you should be able to read this one too!

examples.en: Interacting with that doctor was wonderful.
examples.ja: あの医者の対応は素晴らしかった。

examples.en: Koichi is busy right now addressing complaints from WaniKani users.
examples.ja: コウイチは、今ワニカニユーザーからのクレームに対応していて忙しい。

examples.en: The clerk's service was a godsend. When I tried to negotiate the price down, she immediately gave me a 5,000 yen discount off the regular price with a smile.
examples.ja: あの店員、マジ神対応だったよ。値下げ交渉しようとしたら、すぐに笑顔で定価から五千円も値引きしてくれたの。

meaning_mnemonic: How you <kanji>respond</kanji> <kanji>versus</kanji> someone else is how you're <vocabulary>dealing with</vocabulary> them. It's your <vocabulary>response</vocabulary> to their words and actions.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I was told to stand by at home, but I snuck out and got a hamburger at McDonald's.
examples.ja: 家で待機するように言われてたんだけど、こっそり外出してマクドナルドでハンバーガーを買ってきちゃった。

examples.en: Tofugu engineers are always on call to respond to any WaniKani bugs.
examples.ja: トーフグのエンジニアは、いつでもワニカニのバグに対応できるよう、常に待機している。

examples.en: If birth rates are declining, why are waitlists for schools increasing?
examples.ja: 少子化なのにどうして待機児童が増えるんですか？

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>wait</kanji>ing <kanji>machine</kanji> is a machine on <vocabulary>standby</vocabulary>.  This word doesn’t always apply to machines though. It could be a person who’s on standby, in which case you might also say they’re <vocabulary>on call</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Why can't you just obediently say thank you?
examples.ja: どうして素直に有り難うって言うことができないの？

examples.en: "Congratulations on the birth of your baby." "Thank you very much."
examples.ja: 「赤ちゃんのご誕生、おめでとうございます。」「有難うございます。」

examples.en: Thanks to you, I've been accused of tax evasion.
examples.ja: 有難う。お陰で脱税で告訴されたよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
Some people <kanji>have</kanji> a <kanji>difficult</kanji> time saying <vocabulary>thank you</vocabulary>. But not you now that you know how!

This is often written in kana, so you don't need to use the kanji when writing. But you'll sometimes see the kanji used so it's important to be able to recognize them! Did you know this is an abbreviation of 有難うございます? You can also spell it like this: 有難う.
reading_mnemonic: You've heard people say ありがとう before right?!

examples.en: I haven’t picked out a souvenir yet.
examples.ja: まだお土産を選んでいません。

examples.en: This is a souvenir from the time I went on a bus trip to Kyoto.
examples.ja: これは京都へバス旅行に行った時のお土産です。

examples.en: When my mother traveled to the U.S., she bought tons of souvenirs for her friends and colleagues, but not a single one for herself.
examples.ja: 母はアメリカに旅行に来た時、友達や同僚へのお土産を大量に買い込んでいたが、自分へのお土産は一つも買わなかった。

meaning_mnemonic: Are you visiting a neat place? Grab some <kanji>dirt</kanji> and bring it back with you. Then pretend to <kanji>give birth</kanji> to it in front of your friends. That dirt is now a special <vocabulary>souvenir</vocabulary>! It's the best <vocabulary>present</vocabulary> you could ever give someone!
reading_mnemonic:
These readings are exceptions, sorry! Here's a mnemonic to help you:

When someone asks you who gave you a <vocabulary>souvenir</vocabulary>, just say "<reading>Miya ga</reading>ve (みやげ) it to me." Who's Miya? No idea. But neither do they. You never have to remember who gave you anything ever again! Miya gave you everything you own. She's probably a great person.

examples.en: Even if you die, don't give up on learning kanji!
examples.ja: 死んでも漢字の勉強を諦めないで！

examples.en: Koichi finally abandoned his dream of becoming a Pokemon master.
examples.ja: コウイチはついにポケモンマスターになる夢を諦めた。

examples.en: Doing a mountain of reviews without giving up or resetting—it's a difficult choice.
examples.ja: 山のようなレビューを諦めずにやるかリセットするかは、とても難しい選択です。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>give up</kanji> or <kanji>abandon</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to give up</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to abandon</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
You hopefully learned this reading with the kanji, but here's a reminder just in case:

Just before you're ready <vocabulary>to give up</vocabulary> on something, you yell, "<reading>AKIRA</reading> (あきら)!". You don't know anyone named Akira, you just saw it in a movie once and it made sense, you know? So now when you've tried really hard on something, but you have to abandon it anyway, you shout AKIRA into the sky. I just did it while trying to write this mnemonic!

examples.en: Hey, your sleeve seems dirty.
examples.ja: ねえ、袖が汚れているよ。

examples.en: This polo shirt's sleeves are so short that people mistakenly thought it had none.
examples.ja: このポロシャツ、袖が短すぎてノースリーブに間違われたんだよね。

examples.en: I can't tell anyone that I almost got hit by a car because I couldn't stop staring at the blood vessels that were showing on my senpai's arms from under his sleeves.
examples.ja: 先輩の袖から見えた腕の血管に見とれて車にひかれそうになったなんて誰にも言えない。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You already learned the kun'yomi reading for this kanji, so you should be good to go!

examples.en: They were words that struck a chord in my heart.
examples.ja: それは心に刺さる言葉だった。

examples.en: An arrow embedded itself in his head.
examples.ja: 矢が頭に刺さった。

examples.en: Be careful not to get pricked by a thorn.
examples.ja: トゲが刺さらないように気をつけてね。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.

This is an intransitive verb, meaning that the piercing just happens, without emphasis on what makes it happen. That's why it means <vocabulary>to pierce into</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to stick in</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to stab into</vocabulary>. 

This is a tricky word because its English translations often end up being transitive, but in Japanese we always use this with the particle に, not を, so it's intransitive. You can see this in phrases like 言葉が心に刺さった (the words pierced my heart).
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading.

Lucky for you, the kanji readings for transitive and intransitive verbs are almost always the same. Once you learn one, you know them both! This reading is the same as 刺す.
